pr_title: Log warn when license does not permit auditing

timeline.message: Log when license does not permit audits

timeline.author: ywangd

timeline.bodyText: Without volatile means we could end up logging more frequently than every 30 mins from different threads. Do we care?
timeline.author: ywangd

replies.bodyText:
Hmmm, yeah, in a loaded server there could be many groups of such logs.
I think we should strive to keep reads of the instant from a thread local cache and reach to the main memory only in the case that logging is due. But I ended up using an AtomicReference after trying with a volatile in addition with the regular instance variable.
I'm undecided but I think the atomic reference is good enough.
replies.author: albertzaharovits

replies.bodyText:
I think we should strive to keep reads of the instant from a thread local cache and reach to the main memory only in the case that logging is due.

I agree this would probably be more efficient. But I also agree the AtomicReference is OK. Because this is a warning situation and ideally users should take action to rectify the warnings. Otherwise, it is OK if things could run a tiny bit inefficiently in this non-ideal situation.
replies.author: ywangd

replies.bodyText: Btw, the use of AtomicReference does not fully prevent "logging more than once every 30 mins", nor does using volatile either. They do reduce the chance of it happening and we seem to be content with its effect, e.g. both ApiKeyService and TokenService has a volatile variable to track last expiration run. So I don't think we need to resort to stronger guarantees (e.g. rw lock) here.
replies.author: ywangd

replies.bodyText: Please scratch the above comment, I just noticed the logging call is wrapped inside a compareAndSet. This should solve the problem of "no more than once per 30 mins".
replies.author: ywangd

timeline.bodyText: Nit: should it be Auditing logging ... instead of Security auditing ...? It is true that auditing events are all security related, also this is how the feature Enum is named. But the feature is documented and marketed as "audit logging", which seems to be a better end-user oriented term.
timeline.author: ywangd
